title: Bug: remappings are not supported for `node_modules` dependencies

labels.name: status:ready
labels.description: This issue is ready to be worked on

body:
### Describe the feature

Scenario:

- Hardhat + Foundry project
- Install the npm package of a Foundry project, e.g. [`@sablier/v2-core`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@sablier/v2-core)
- Add the proper remappings in `remappings.txt`, i.e. `@sablier/v2-core/=node_modules/@sablier/v2-core/src/`
- Import something from `@sablier/v2/core`, e.g. `import { LockupLinear } from "@sablier/v2-core/types/DataTypes.sol";`
- Hope that the import works

But the import does not work:

```text
Failed to resolve file: "/Users/prb/Workspace/templates/hardhat-template/node_modules/@sablier/v2-core/types/DataTypes.sol": No such file or directory (os error 2).
 Check configured remappings..
    --> "/Users/prb/Workspace/templates/hardhat-template/contracts/Greeter.sol"
        "@sablier/v2-core/types/DataTypes.sol"
```

It seems to me that what happens is that Hardhat disregards the remappings in `remappings.txt` when it finds a matching path in `node_modules`.

The feature request is to make remappings work with `node_modules`.

FWIW, this is a blocker for our integration partners that are on Hardhat. They have to copy-paste the Sablier code for now.

### Search terms

foundry,hardhat-foundry

### Environment

- node@18.16.0
- hardhat@2.17.0

@fvictorio I think we should consider this to be a bug, right? If it's present in the local `remappings.txt` shouldn't that take priority? As there's an explicit intention set by the user to use the remmapped path.

This is the root of the issue: https://github.com/NomicFoundation/hardhat/blob/main/packages/hardhat-foundry/src/foundry.ts#L49

We should check if it's an explicit remapping in `remappings.txt` and not ignore it.

We continued exploring this with @fvictorio, and we'll fix it in the next sprint (starting tomorrow).

The fix should:
1. Check in the line posted above if the remapping is in `remappings.txt`, if it is, do not ignore it. — This would not work with `foundry.toml`, so there's probably better approaches to consider.
2. In [hardhat core's resolver](https://github.com/NomicFoundation/hardhat/blob/main/packages/hardhat-core/src/internal/solidity/resolver.ts#L112): don't treat replaced `importName`s as importNames, but as file paths AND source names instead.

This bug continues to be a blocker for our users:

https://github.com/sablier-labs/v2-core/issues/646
I'll be working on this today, so we should be able to release a fix early next week.

I'm super confused about this, to be honest. I think that `forge` is creating a wrong input for solc (or at least that's what it seems to me by looking at the build-info after running `forge build --build-info`), in the sense that the solc input is not self-contained. But it works because solc seems to be reading from the file system anyway even when used in standard json mode :confused: :confused:

I asked the solc team about this. If they confirm that this is a bug, then forge is working in this case because the solc bug cancels its own bug. If they say that this is intentional (which would be super weird, ngl), the I still think forge is doing something wrong because the generated input is not correct. This can affect contract verification, for example, unless I'm seriously missing something here.

That doesn't explain the problem in our side though! But I found that weird thing while looking into this, so I'm mentioning it here for completeness.

Btw, I'm re-opening this because it's clearly not fixed.

One clarification because I was wrong: the solc behavior is a feature, not a bug. It's a feature I would love to be able to turn off, but that's [not possible right now](https://github.com/NomicFoundation/hardhat/issues/4290).

Aight, so, to understand @fvictorio — we still have a bug here? Just catching up to the convo. Happy to help to fix this or settle into some common way of handling this so users can use hardhat & forge without issue

Hey @Evalir, sorry for the confusion.

Yes, I think there is at least one scenario where forge creates a solc input that (unintentionally, I guess) depends on the default import callback used by solc. I shared some details and reproduction steps with @mds1.

At the very least I recommend doing something like what I mention in https://github.com/NomicFoundation/hardhat/issues/4290, since that will prevent non-self-contained inputs from working.

Posting aforementioned repro from @fvictorio below:

```
mkdir repro && cd repro
forge init

# remove tests and scripts to make the solc input more clear
rm -r test script

# install @prb/math with pnpm
pnpm init && pnpm install @prb/math

# modify the source file to import something from @prb/math
echo 'import "@prb/math/SD1x18.sol";' >> src/Counter.sol

# add remapping
echo "@prb/math/=node_modules/@prb/math/src/" > remappings.txt

# build and generate the build info file
forge build --build-info

# get the solc input and _put it in another directory_
jq .input out/build-info/*.json > ~/Desktop/input.json

# compile that solc input in that directory
cd ~/Desktop
solc --standard-json input.json
```

> Using pnpm is important, this doesn't happen with npm
> Also, I specifically imported SD1x18.sol and not, say, Common.sol because the former has relative imports while the latter doesn't. I'm mentioning this because I think it's an important hint to what's going on. If you look at the sources in the input.json file you'll see that the imports get broken when you get to SD1x18.sol, because the source name units of the files it depends on are something like node_modules/.pnpm/... instead of node_modules/@prb/math/....
> My first guess is that it's something related to symlinks
